content.text: On Fig.1.1, measure the distance \(x\) from the centre of the modelling clay to the pivot
On Fig.1.1, measure the distance \(y\) from the pivot to the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark on the rule

A student moulds a piece of modelling clay into a cube shape. He places the modelling clay on the rule so that its centre is a distance \(d = 10.0 \text{cm}\) from the zero end of the rule, as shown in Fig.1.1
He adjusts the position of the rule so that it is as near as possible to being balanced, with the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark to the right of the pivot
Calculate the actual distance \(X\) from the centre of the modelling clay to the pivot
Calculate the actual distance \(Y\) from the pivot to the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark on the rule
Calculate the mass \(m_{1}\) of the piece of modelling clay using the equation
where the mass of the metre rule \(M = 112 \text{g}\)
The diagram is drawn one tenth of actual size

parts.label: (c)

content.text: The student cuts the piece of modelling clay into two pieces, with one piece at twice the size of the other piece
Using the larger piece of modelling clay, he repeats the procedure and obtains a result for mass \(m_{2}\) of \(64.9 \text{g}\)
Using the smaller piece of modelling clay, he repeats the procedure and obtains a result for the mass \(m_{3}\) of \(34.5 \text{g}\)
Calculate \((m_{2} + m_{3})\)

issues: LaTeX subscript (_) found outside math mode
LaTeX subscript (_) found outside math mode

content.text: Assuming that the experiment has been carried out with care, suggest two reasons why \((m_{2} + m_{3})\) may not be equal to \(m_{1}\)
Explain briefly how you would ensure that the centre of the cube of modelling clay is at the \(10.0 \text{cm}\) mark on the metre rule. You may draw a diagram
[Total: 9]
The IGCSE class is investigating the law of moments
Fig. 1.1 shows the apparatus used
The temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{c}}\) of the cold water is \(24^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
She pours \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of the hot water into a beaker. Record the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{h}}\) of this water, as shown on the thermometer
Complete the volume column in the table, where \(V\) is the total volume of cold water so far added
Complete the column headings in the table

She adds \(10 \text{cm}^3\) of the cold water to the beaker of hot water. She briefly stirs the mixture of hot and cold water and records in Table 2.1 the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{m}}\) of the mixture of hot and cold water. She quickly repeats this five times, adding \(10 \text{cm}^3\) of cold water each time, until a total of \(60 \text{cm}^3\) has been added. She records the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{m}}\) of the mixture of hot and cold water at each stage
Plot the graph of temperature \(\theta\) (\(y\)-axis) against volume \(V\) (\(x\)-axis)
If this experiment were to be repeated in order to check the results, it would be important to control the conditions. Suggest two such conditions that should be controlled
Suggest a practical precaution that will enable readings in this experiment to be taken as accurately as possible
An IGCSE student is investigating temperature changes when hot water and cold water
She is provided with a supply of hot water and a supply of cold water
A student measures the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{A}}\) across resistor \(\mathbf{R}_{1}\)
Write down the reading of \(V_{\mathrm{A}}\) shown in Fig. 3.2
Calculate \((V_{\mathrm{A}} + V_{\mathrm{B}})\)
State whether the experimental results support the theory. Justify your reference to the results
statement
justification

He then measures the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{B}}\) across resistors \(\mathbf{R}_{2}\) and \(\mathbf{R}_{3}\) and the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{C}}\) across the combination of the three resistors
The values are: \(V_{\mathrm{B}} = 1.4 \text{V}\) and \(V_{\mathrm{C}} = 2.1 \text{V}\)
Theory suggests that \(V_{\mathrm{C}} = (V_{\mathrm{A}} + V_{\mathrm{B}})\)
The current \(I\) indicated by the ammeter is \(0.27 \text{A}\). Calculate the resistance \(R\) of the combination of the three resistors using the equation \(R = \frac{V_{\text{C}}}{I}\)
On Fig. 3.1, draw in the voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{B}}\) across resistors \(\mathbf{R}_{2}\) and \(\mathbf{R}_{3}\). Use the standard symbol for a voltmeter
Refer to Fig. 3.2. Comment on the student's choice of the \(10\mathrm{V}\) range for the measurement of \(V_{\mathrm{A}}\)
The IGCSE class is investigating the potential difference across resistors in a circuit
Fig. 3.1 shows the circuit
Draw a normal to \(\mathbf{MR}\) at its centre. Label the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\) with \(\mathbf{N}\) at the centre of \(\mathbf{MR}\) and \(\mathbf{L}\) on \(\mathbf{AB}\)
Mark a point on \(\mathbf{AB}\), 3.0cm to the left of \(\mathbf{L}\). Label this point \(\mathbf{C}\)
The line \(\mathbf{MR}\) shows the position of a mirror
Draw the line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\). Continue the line until it meets the normal
Draw the line joining point \(\mathbf{C}\) and point \(\mathbf{N}\)

Measure, and record in Table 4.1, the angle of incidence \(i\) between the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\) and the line \(\mathbf{CN}\). Measure, and record in the table, the angle of reflection \(r\) between the normal and the line passing through \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\)
Complete the column headings in the table
Fig. 4.2 shows the mirror which is made of polished metal and has a vertical line
The lower end of this line is at point \(\mathbf{N}\)

In the experiment, the student places a pin \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) at \(\mathbf{C}\). The student views the line on the mirror and the image of pin \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 4.1. She places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) some distance apart so that the image of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\), the line on the mirror, and pins \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\), all appear exactly one behind the other. The positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) are shown
The student repeats the procedure using positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) that are \(4.0 \text{cm}\) and \(5.0 \text{cm}\) from the normal. The readings are shown in the table

In spite of carrying out this experiment with reasonable care, it is possible that the values of the angle of reflection \(r\) will not be exactly the same as the values obtained from theory. Suggest two possible causes of this inaccuracy
Suggest one precaution that you would take in this experiment to ensure that the as accurate as possible
An IGCSE student is investigating the reflection of light by a plane mirror
Fig. 4.1 shows her ray trace sheet
Complete the column headings in Table 5.1
Complete the third column in the table by calculating the extension \(e\) of the spring
State whether the results support the suggestion that the extension is directly proportional the load. Justify your answer by reference to the results
statement
justification
Draw a diagram of the apparatus including the spring, clamp, a weight hanging on the spring and a ruler positioned to measure the length of the spring
The IGCSE class is investigating springs

A student measures the length \(l_{\mathrm{0}}\) of a spring and then uses a stand and clamp to suspend the spring vertically. He hangs a weight \(W\) on the spring and measures the new length \(l.\) He calculates the extension \(e\) of the spring. He repeats the procedure using a range of weights
Table 5.1 shows some readings obtained by the student. The unstretched length \(l_{\mathrm{0}}\) of the spring is \(16\mathrm{mm}\)
